text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"I've been looking for a full-time role for a couple of months now and I haven't even heard back from most companies. I find it super difficult as someone outside of the U.S. to land a remote role in content. Any thoughts on this?"

Hey, I’ve also been there. I live in Africa and have a “managerial role” in a California based SaaS.  I think the #1 thing you should do is to change your mindset. Most of us who are not in the US tend to downplay ourselves when applying. So, focus on being a “Content Marketer” and not a “Content Marketer Living Outside of the US.”

#2 It’s not a debate, it’s hard for us (outsiders) to get a job in the US. Recognize that and work 10x more than the others. You need to do something that stands out when applying. If your profile is not that impressive, try internships or part time jobs. For me, it was to work as a part time journalist for the British media. The pay was bad but I learned. And it helped me get some more eyeballs on my resume.

#3 Always be willing to do more than the scope of work or what they asked for. If they said do ABC, do ABC and say I thought DEF was also going to help. It’s all about bringing in some more value.

#4 Network! Build meaningful relationships and be patient.

#5 Instead of targeting big fishes like Hubspot, Drift, and Salesforce, target startups. Remember, you’re looking for someone to give you a shot and pay you to learn.

Hope that helps!

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Hey all! After a couple of years as a content marketing manager heading up a team of three, my manager (the CMO) has asked me to begin thinking about my career trajectory and which skills areas I see myself building upon.

I've got SEO under my belt with a sprinkle of product, but I'm curious to hear from others about other specialisations/channels that sit parallel to content and have been a great addition to their content tool kit.

Currently, I'm very much tied up in the weeds, so the plan is to take some of that away so I can focus more on strategy. But I'm a little stuck on the 'where to next?' bit. 

As a side note, I'd love to hear from those who have been promoted from content marketing manager and what your next step was. What changed, and how did you get there? Doesn't even have to be in the realm of content — I've heard of people moving into digital product manager roles from content, so keen to hear more about those experiences also.

Thanks so much :)"
